instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Hello all. I got a board that was not powering on. After inspection I found corrosion around <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>. Put some flux on it, set my TR1300 station to 350 Celsius with medium airflow and gave it some heat. After 20 seconds or so the top layer seemed to pop and went back into position. I tried recalling the SMC and replacing it also, but still no green light. I have no shorts and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.15V instead of 8.56V. I think that popped layer broke something internally to the board. Any way to verify that or the board is junk?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Do you get correct <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and now I get around 0.5V on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
No good; check <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>.
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>@100K
3V42 = 3.42V Stable
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.16V stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
Remove first <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
If still the same, disconnect trackpad flex and test again.
If still low, clean/remove J6100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Correct me if I'm wrong, but by what I understood of what you told I should remove <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and plug in the board? Would't that fry the board because the lack of PWM control?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Sorry, my mistake; read <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> instead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Removed <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and J6100. Still same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
"disconnect trackpad flex and test again."
Did?

Remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: It's out the case. Nothing but IO board and cable connected. Removed <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and still Low <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, around 1,1V and going down up to 0.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
Change <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>, just in case.
Also heat SMC, to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Replaced the resistor and recalled SMC. Same thing. I had already tried replacing the SMC before but same results.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
So you had SMC removed from the board.
Did you check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level then?

Post now all <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>:

Pin 1 - 3.42V
Pin 2 - 0V
Pin 3 - 3.4V
Pin 4 - 2.77V
Pin 5 - 0V
Pin 6 - 3.42V
Pin 7 - 3.4V
Pin 8 - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> again.
Post diode mode to ground at pins 5 & 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>:

Pin 1 - 3.42V
Pin 2 - 0V
Pin 3 - 3.4V
Pin 4 - 2.77V
Pin 5 - 0V
Pin 6 - 3.42V
Pin 7 - 3.4V
Pin 8 - 3.4V

Diode:

Pin 5 - 0.003
Pin 8 - 0.523

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Apparently, Pin 8 shorted to GND

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, short gone and now I get orange light on charger(no green light though), but <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> still low near 0.9V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message:
"Pin 8 shorted to GND"
Did you mean pin 5?

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> should be good now, if you get Magsafe amber light.
Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?

Green light only comes back when battery is fully charged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Yes, I meant Pin 5, was a mistype. Light is amber, but even without battery, normal behavior should be green light fir a couple of seconds then amber. Mine gets only amber and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is still under 1V. Yes, genuine MagSafe 2 85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Well, I gave <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area some heat and now the board started giving <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal 3.4V. Now the board is entering S3 state. I have all power rails in sequence up to <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: And... Suddenly it stopped again! Same low reading on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, no light no charger

Did ot?
Let the board to cool down first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Corrosion Near <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> No Power
threads.message: Force the signal with 33K in place of <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>.
